content: Articles published on 29 April and 1 May, and since deleted, followed up on reports in other media outlets, originally published by a law firm, about little-known laws that could affect British citizens.

In one article we repeated claims that it is illegal to use your phone to pay for food at a drive-through restaurant while your engine is running. In fact, while using your mobile when operating a vehicle is subject to strict legislation, there an exemption in the Highway Code for drivers who are using a mobile phone to make an immediate contactless payment at a payment terminal where the vehicle is stationary. There is no requirement to turn off the car's engine.In the second article we suggested that placing a stamp upside-down on an envelope may be considered to fall under the auspices of the Treason Felony Act 1848. The Act does not refer to stamps and, according to Royal Mail, placing a stamp upside-down would have no legal ramifications. To report an inaccuracy, please email corrections@mailonline.co.uk. To make a formal complaint under IPSO rules please go to www.mailonline.co.uk/readerseditor where you will find an easy-to-use complaints form. You can also write to Readers' Editor, MailOnline, Northcliffe House, 2 Derry Street, London W8 5TT or contact IPSO directly at ipso.co.uk
